context.p: To install Eucalyptus on servers running Ubuntu 10.04 LTS:

step.cmd: Create a file in /etc/apt/sources.list.d called eucalyptus.list with the following content:
If you are a Eucalyptus subscriber, copy your credentials so the package managers can locate them. If you are not a Eucalyptus subscriber, skip this step.

substep.cmd: Copy the entitlement certificate to the /etc/ssl/certs directory on each server that you want to install Eucalyptus on.
Copy the private key file to the /etc/ssl/private directory on each server that you want to install Eucalyptus on.

info.note: Make sure that the private key's file permissions are restricted to only the root user and ssl-certs group.

substep.cmd: Add the public key to the list of trusted keys.

On all machines that will run either Eucalyptus or Euca2ools, create a file in /etc/apt/sources.list.d called euca2ools.list with the following content:
Enter the following command on all machines:
Install Eucalyptus packages and dependencies. The following example shows a package install all on the same server. You can install each component on a different server.

info.codeblock: apt-get install eucalyptus-cloud eucalyptus-cc eucalyptus-sc eucalyptus-walrus

step.cmd: On each planned NC server, install the NC package:

info.note: If you are using VMware, you can skip this step. Eucalyptus software is not installed on the node machines. The nodes are running VMware.

step.cmd: If you are a Eucalyptus subscriber and plan to use VMware, install the subscription-only VMware Broker package on each CC server:
If you are a Eucalyptus subscriber and plan to use SAN support, install the subscription-only SAN package on each SC. Otherwise, skip this step.

taskbody.postreq: You are now ready to Configure Eucalyptus.
